title: Social listening of City Scale Events using the Streaming Linked Data Framework

author: Emanuele Della Valle, Politecnico di Milano

segmentation: Thank you for the introduction for coming to the session.
This is a joint work that me and colleagues of mine Mark and Daniella did together with people from University of Trento, Mick and Tim is an accompanying Milano studio label that runs the website.

One big event that we have every year which is called Milano Forest Alona which is all the events that are during Milan Design Week when there is one of the largest furniture fairs in the world in Milano.
My talk will introduce a bit what I mean by city scale.
Events will tell you why we believe that stream processing can be a one way to handle this.
Listening of city scale event.
Then I will focus on our technology and I will show you how we put it at work in a couple of use cases.
So a city scale event is a set of events that are somehow talking something.
About one single topic, there are spread across the city, multiple venue, and they tend to attract many people.
Just give the example Olympic Games.
They basically treat about sport and they are spread across many different variants but tend to attract a lot of people.
Millions of tickets mostly sold and this is the other thing that I was talking about before.
Like a big furniture fail with all the satellite events in this case in Milano we have something that last one week with 600 venues spread across the city.
Anne really attracts many people, half a million more or less no.
Let me give you a bit of problem statement.
So for instance here in London we were trying to track the movement over crowds only looking at social streams.

Nothing else on the point is that of course there are way to do it now, so you use CCTV, you use mobile network data, you spread people around which is very effective, no doubt, but it's really expensive too and it would be very nice to obtain somehow similar results by using social streams.
In the case of Milan Design Week, we have a company studio album.
That somehow organized with big website and they also ask money to sponsor and this sponsor want to know where are very effective, not in communicating the presence of event in the city.
Of course they can do it so they put people around into the city and they measure how many people go to each event.
And again this is expensive.
So what if you can do similar thing by using social media?
By analyzing these, we got some how many requirements and the Model S. This is what we end up with.
So we need to assess this social media.
We need to record them because maybe later on we want to do more analysis on the same data and this also requires to replay these social streams.

Are in many cases the stream itself is not reaching us, so you have to decorate it, link into some knowledge base, adding sentiment things like that and to analyze it and we would like to do it in real time.

So you need continuous analysis, but even if you do after today, recording data can be so large that you probably need some continuous analysis fashion, and normally you cannot do this with just one query or just one decorator.
You need to put this stuff into workflow.
Last, we are dealing with people that want to see results, so they are not happy to see tables, so they actually want visualizations.
So we have to publish this data and to visualize them.

What we came up with is a framework that we call streaming link data, so it's a link data that tried to somehow deal with streams and we made it a publish subscribe system because we wanted to act in real time and we want to couple publisher from subscribers.
We need reliable message passing because we don't want somehow to deal with all these out of order stuff that can happen in reality.
And we want to minimize latency because we want to do this in real time, so entire system is main memory and does not access the disk unless you have to write the stream.
That's the only reason why we are.
We go down to.
To the disk, and this is the architecture.
So we have one side with data sources on the other side we have clients where we display the results and in the middle you have this streaming link data server.

Vidya is that data sources stream, something you have adapters for multiple sources that put with whatever data format into RDF, and then where is the bus to have if anything that is streamed through the bus can be analyzed and create a new stream.
And of course you can always take a stream and do a decoration on it and re inject it.
And you can record any stream that is in the bus or create stream out of something that you recall and inject it into the bus.
In the end, you can publish these streams and you can add visualizers that will present the.

So going back there, adapters will somehow transform whatever is outside into RDF and visit an example of famous tweet that was done during the Olympic game by Tim Berners Lee and as you can see I mean, it's pretty simple.
We're simply using shock, nothing else.
When we go down to this bus here, the point is that is a publisher scribe system, where you can have all these analyzer composer, re players and whatever else set in a workflow.
So later on you will see this kind of workflows.
That is the way we design the application.
To publish the data we use link data, but we extend them a bit because you need to keep the information that arrive in the same moment in one consistent system.
So what we do is we use named graph and we have one named graph 2.2 sequence of limit graph that contains based on tinies set of triple that somehow capture apart of information.

This is also used in the recordings of recording is simply set writing down on the disk with instantaneous graph and keeping track in another graph of whatever graph you have writing down, and there is a bunch of metadata that you can use to talk this information when it was received.
What you did on top of it, provenance and whatever as you want.

The analyzers are written in a language, but we called the sparkle is a extension of sparkle for continuous query on top of RDF streams on somehow gives you the power of sparkle, but you also add survey notion of window and it allow you to specify things like this where you are stating that there is some window of 15 minutes and how it moves.
So every minute this one will go on and very queries counting.
Which are the most frequently used hashtag?
The decorators, as I was saying before, are simple sparkle query that get a pattern into the data.
They somehow use it too.
Call some external services and then add to the same graph more triples and put it back into the bus.
And David.
Elisar are bunch of visualization written in HTML5 that connect to streaming link data that are published and publish them.
No, let me.
Go to the case study so the first one was can we detect events during the Olympic Games?
We have quite a number of tweets, so Twitter sent us 3 million tweets located in the area of the Olympic Stadium and there are three big venues.
Their Olympic Stadium itself, which is a big venue of Aquatic Center, which is a bit smaller and there is water polar area which is quite small.
Part and the idea is that we have a ground truth, which is the calendar of Olympic game.
So what we did?
Year was taking the stream and coming up with a network of query that try to check whether there is an event the way it does.

It is very trivial, so it counts the number of tweets that come from various area around the stadium, so it counts those that are in the traffics in the public transport area when it counts votes that are outside with venues and then it counts votes that are inside the venues and after that you have a stream of number.
And out of this stream of number you can do outlier detection, so you can find bursts of tweets that are located in the public transportation outside the venues.

An inside the venues, and so the last step is you come up with a smart way to predict that there is an event based on complex event processing, and here is pretty simple if I've seen a Metro, a bars close to the Metro and after that I see a bars outside the venue.
And I see when it bars in the venue and this is happening at window of Alf an hour when probably an event is starting.
Now in the venue.
These are the results plotted so that.
There are bars here means an event.
The Gray bars are smaller events and the darker one our final events.
And as you can see from the dots that we draw somehow for the Olympics Stadium, we got them all.
We even got some false positive for all very spontaneous event of people that went to Olympics Stadium in the middle.
And more or less we did the same for the water center per season is very.
I also in the water pollorena but very cold drop down and the reason is that there is much less people in these places and so when you're done, I've evidence based systems.
If that does not work.
Now going to Milan Design week.
Here Point is is Milan Design Week visible in such as media and is this attempt to measure cost effective?
We are talking to an S me that somehow spend 10,000 euro to run this website and I don't want to spend 10,000 euro to check whether they are effective, right?
So it must be very cheap for them.
The network is this one and it provides.
Several stuff like this so you have heat Maps you have.
Barchart
You have a graph like this one that captures the number of tweets in the city on.
This is life actually, so if you go to that website to index for this alone and you will actually see what's happening now in Milano.
Texan.
More.
And on we were able to show that Milano Design Week is visible so it's visible in the volume.
So as soon as it starts, you have more tweets and assume its end.
You drop down to the usual situation.
It's.
Visible in terms of number of tweets that are close by important venues so you can rank venues by number of tweets.
Twitter close by.
But unfortunately in this setting we were not able to answer one of the questions that they ask us, which is do people feel what I try to give them.
So we are very more happy when they exit the events.
Unfortunately there was not enough evidence to say anything meaningful.
One of your sponsor of this project was azasan for one of a venue that was in forest alone and Mineral Design Week.
They want to know whether the launch of a product is visible and they want to know exactly this sentiment point.
So this time we were analyzing many more tweets across the world.
We got them not just both Joe located in Milano.
And this is the result that we got, so we were somehow able to capture.
The moment when the lounge was done in Milan, Design week of the foam pad and we were also able to detect the sentiment shifts that this was causing.
So I would say that somehow we are happy with that, but as expected, given that we use a vocabulary based sentiment analyzer, we were somehow not good when sarcasm was involved.
So if you write things like I want to buy this so bad, this means that you are really happy.
But actually we classify these as wrong as bad.
Now concluding.

I see pros and cons in what we did, both in the technical solution and in the application, but we did from a technical perspective, I would say that the choice of RDF in this specific setting is quite appropriate because each tweet is a small graph and you are somehow streaming part of this larger graph where they belong to, so that makes sense.
The coupling.

Their visualization and analysis makes sense because all the visualization was was done by people in Studio Lab, but don't know anything about linked data and somehow adding the decorator is cheap, so that is quite quite nice.
On the other side, if you have to write this analysis, you have to drive.
I'm insist particle which is quite complex.
You require people that know how to do it as an excuse.
I will say that EPL which is 1 popular streaming language is more or less the same so.
Yeah.
And from the social listening perspective, this is an affordable 'cause.
There was a slide that I didn't pay much attention about.
That says cause only 25 euros per month more or less.
And the fact that you can have access to the feeling of the people really help a lot in in answering the question we were asked.
I doubt that this is statistically relevant an some over fat, but sometime you lock volume are paying your results.
Of.
So thank you for listening and if you have any questions I'd be very pleased to answer.
